@podsvirov , can you please comment on the intended meaning of `find_package(protobuf CONFIG)` introduced here: https://github.com/grpc/grpc/pull/7553/files#diff-14d5339fff038df1b7418aa8135bb4e8R130

CC @nicolasnoble

Hello @kskalski and @jtattermusch.

Please read [Using Packages](https://cmake.org/cmake/help/latest/manual/cmake-packages.7.html#using-packages) in CMake documentation to lear the diffirents betwen `CONFIG` ([Config-file Packages](https://cmake.org/cmake/help/latest/manual/cmake-packages.7.html#config-file-packages)) and `MODULE` ([Find-module Packages](https://cmake.org/cmake/help/latest/manual/cmake-packages.7.html#find-module-packages)).

Since version 3.0 protobuf can be built with CMake (officialy on Windows only, but realy on ohter platforms too) and provide `Config-file Package` named `protobuf` with [IMPORTED](https://cmake.org/cmake/help/latest/prop_tgt/IMPORTED.html#prop_tgt:IMPORTED) targets like `protobuf::libprotbuf` and `protobuf::protoc`.
Also CMake have built-in `Find-module Package` named `Protobuf`.
It's two diffirend ways to find protobuf libraries and compiler.

In the beginning, the gRPC's CMake project did not support the use of packages at all.
Then I added an optional support for using `Config-file Packages` and `IMPORTED` targets.
If you want to use `Find-module Packages`, please add support for this new functionality without damaging the existing functionality.

@podsvirov "If you want to use Find-module Packages, please add support for this new functionality without damaging the existing functionality." - isn't it what my change actually does?
From documentation at https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.0/command/find_package.html:
"The command has two modes by which it searches for packages: “Module” mode and “Config” mode. Module mode is available when the command is invoked with the above reduced signature. CMake searches for a file called Find<package>.cmake in the CMAKE_MODULE_PATH followed by the CMake installation. If the file is found, it is read and processed by CMake. It is responsible for finding the package, checking the version, and producing any needed messages. Many find-modules provide limited or no support for versioning; check the module documentation. **If no module is found and the MODULE option is not given the command proceeds to Config mode.**"

So basically having "find_package(protobuf CONFIG)" disables the MODULE mode, while "find_package(Protobuf)" tries both. Note that I kept the checks for protobuf::protoc style targets, so there it should also work fine for both modes. Unfortunately I'm not sure how to test it, on the Raspbian distro that I'm using the only way that works is MODULE-mode, that's why I made the change.

I use `IMPORTED` targets to make [Relocatable Packages](https://cmake.org/cmake/help/latest/manual/cmake-packages.7.html#creating-relocatable-packages). It's some works [!861](https://gitlab.kitware.com/cmake/cmake/merge_requests/861) and [!876](url) in CMake. And it will be useful for me too.
In the near future I will try to provide a solution that will satisfy both of us.

So there's good news and bad news.

:thumbsup: The good news is that everyone that needs to sign a CLA (the pull request submitter and all commit authors) have done so.  Everything is all good there.

:confused: The bad news is that it appears that one or more commits were authored by someone other than the pull request submitter.  We need to confirm that they're okay with their commits being contributed to this project.  Please have them confirm that here in the pull request.

*Note to project maintainer: This is a terminal state, meaning the `cla/google` commit status will not change from this state. It's up to you to confirm consent of the commit author(s) and merge this pull request when appropriate.*

It's not good...
